docs.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, an obese, diabetic patient of mine insisted on knee-replacement surgery against the wishes of her doctors, who believed that it would be too dangerous. She came through with flying colors. While everyone rightly praised the efforts of her surgeon and physical therapist, another factor in her recovery was ignored: luck. Why are doctors and patients so reluctant to discuss a phenomenon that permeates medicine every day?

headline.main: In Science-Based Medicine, Where Does Luck Fit In?

docs.abstract: Dr Barron H Lerner Essay discusses role of luck in medicine; says that some physicians are reluctant to attribute recovery or response to treatment to luck and hold that patients would rather hear biological explanation for success or failure; drawing (M)
